body.p: As part of a business combination, an acquirer may reacquire a right that it had previously granted to the acquiree to use the acquirer’s recognised or unrecognised intangible assets. Examples of such rights include a right to use the acquirer’s trade name under a franchise agreement or a right to use the acquirer’s technology under a technology licensing agreement. The 2005 Exposure Draft proposed, and the revised standards require, an acquirer to recognise such a reacquired right as an identifiable intangible asset (paragraph B35 of the revised IFRS 3). The fair value of a reacquired right is to be amortised over the remaining term of the contract that gave rise to the right. For entities applying US GAAP, that guidance is not new; it is the same as the related guidance in EITF Issue 04‑1. (Paragraphs BC308–BC310 discuss the measurement of reacquired rights.)
